29.28.text: 14 teams of distinguished alumni have entertained us

32.48.text: over the past few days with, on the whole,

34.68.text: an impressive display of what they know.

36.92.text: What many of them don't know, it turns out,

39.20.text: is when to use their buzzers in this contest and when not to.

42.92.text: But we've only been playing the game for 54 years,

45.00.text: and these things do take time to sink in.

47.76.text: But now, only the best two teams remain,

49.68.text: and in a little under half an hour,

51.52.text: one of them will become series champions,

55.88.text: than the right to look immensely pleased with themselves.

59.48.text: Now, the team from Leeds University had a very comfortable win

61.92.text: over the School of Oriental and African Studies

65.32.text: but they were trailing behind the University of Kent

69.40.text: When they finally got a grip and had put themselves on level pegging

73.00.text: at the gong, the tie-break question went their way.

76.16.text: They may never have been so pleased

78.12.text: to know about the Tigris and the Euphrates.

79.88.text: LAUGHTER Let's ask the Leeds team

82.44.text: to introduce themselves for the last time.

86.40.text: I graduated from Leeds in 1984 with a degree in English literature,

90.32.text: and I now write novels for a living.

93.16.text: Hello, I'm Gus Unger-Hamilton. I, too, read English at Leeds,

96.00.text: graduating in 2010, and I now play in the band alt-J.

102.36.text: I graduated in political studies from Leeds in 1990,

105.64.text: and I'm now the Economics Editor of the BBC.

111.08.text: I graduated from Leeds in fine art in 1974,

115.04.text: and I've been drawing political cartoons

123.88.text: The team from St Hilda's College Oxford

126.36.text: beat Magdalene College Cambridge in their first-round match

132.36.text: Then, in the rare spectacle of an all-female fixture,

135.32.text: they beat St Anne's College Oxford by 165 points to 75.

139.96.text: Let's meet them for the last time.

144.64.text: I graduated in medicine from St Hilda's in 1966,

148.60.text: and I now chair a large teaching hospital trust in Oxford,

152.40.text: and I'm the National Data Guardian for health and social care.

158.08.text: I read classics at St Hilda's from 2005 to 2009,

162.20.text: and I'm now an author and journalist.

167.24.text: I graduated from St Hilda's in 1975 with a degree in English,

174.88.text: I read modern languages at St Hilda's between 1963 and '66,

186.00.text: OK, the rules are unchanging on this contest,

188.16.text: let's just get on with it.

189.44.text: Fingers on the buzzers, here's your first starter for ten.

192.16.text: William Sandys' Christmas Carols Ancient And Modern

195.96.text: was first published during the reign of which British monarch?

202.48.text: Victoria, I was going to say, sorry.

204.68.text: I'm afraid you lose five points.

206.60.text: His reign also saw the Slavery Abolition Act

209.92.text: and the passage of the Great Reform Bill.

217.52.text: It was William IV, yes. APPLAUSE

222.32.text: The first bonuses are on writing about winter, St Hilda's.

226.16.text: In a novel of 1950, which fictional country is first encountered

230.40.text: in the grip of an apparently permanent winter?

233.04.text: As one character explains, "It's always winter.

235.80.text: "Always winter, and never Christmas. Think of that."

243.00.text: "that he has got through the perils of winter

247.36.text: Who wrote those words in the novel Dr Thorne, first published 1858?

254.40.text: Which would complete this couplet from Byron's poem Don Juan,

261.04.text: "The English winter, ending in July to recommence in..."

273.16.text: Differing only in their second letter,

275.04.text: which two words mean "to roll about in mud" and "a tree of the genus..."

288.32.text: These bonuses for you, Leeds, your first set,

292.80.text: Firstly, for five points, from the Latin for "cut",

295.60.text: what term is used in poetry for a division or pause

299.44.text: between two words in a metrical foot?

307.16.text: what term can be used both for

308.96.text: a gap between two structures within the human body

312.04.text: and for the space between two adjacent atoms in a crystal lattice?

324.40.text: Which six-letter word appears in the name of

326.80.text: a particular form of abdominal hernia?

329.28.text: More generally, it means a physical, logical or temporal gap.

334.48.text: Temporal gap... A space, a pause...

339.96.text: I'm not getting it. I'm not getting that.

344.56.text:
- Sorry, we don't know. Oh... 
- Hiatus, hiatus.

352.28.text: Just in the nick of time. Ten points for this.

358.72.text: of which painter, born in Normandy in 1594?

362.36.text: His works include The Death Of The Virgin

364.72.text: and A Dance To Music Of Time.

376.92.text: Three questions on the periodic table, St Hilda's, for your bonuses.

380.52.text: Sometimes called rare earths, what name is given

383.76.text: to the series of metallic elements with atomic numbers 57 to 71?

399.92.text: Secondly, what term denotes the series

402.16.text: of highly radioactive elements with atomic numbers 89 to 103?

418.32.text: And finally, what actinoid element has the atomic number of 94?

428.36.text: We're going to take a picture round now.

430.20.text: For your picture starter, I want you to name the figure indicated

433.76.text: by the clues in the image you're about to see,

436.48.text: which will give the location with which he's primarily associated,

439.92.text: the approximate dates of his life, and his feast day.

449.28.text: Anyone like to buzz from St Hilda's?

451.00.text: You may not confer. One of you may buzz.

459.56.text: It is St Nicholas, yes. APPLAUSE

464.28.text: He's regarded, of course, as the origin of Santa Claus.

467.36.text: For your bonuses, three more saints associated with the festive season.

470.88.text: Five points for each you can identify.

472.84.text: Firstly, this saint from the approximate dates of his life,

476.04.text: the location with which he's most associated, and his feast day?

489.72.text: No, it's St Martin of Tours,

491.76.text: whose day used to mark the start of Advent.

494.36.text: Secondly, this saint from her approximate dates,

498.64.text: and her feast day, which falls during Advent.

508.64.text: No, it's St Lucia of Syracuse.

511.92.text: from the date and location of his martyrdom and his feast day.

525.00.text: Named as Portugal's Viceroy in India by King John III in 1524,

529.16.text: which explorer died in China on Christmas Eve in that year...?

535.48.text: No, I'm afraid you lose five points.

540.00.text: You could have heard the rest of the question,

542.36.text: which would have made it inevitable you would get Vasco da Gama,

546.60.text: and I must accept the answer you give when you buzz.

550.80.text: What seven-letter word links terms meaning "a prehistoric refuse heap",

555.32.text: "an informal coterie of political advisors" and...?

565.40.text: That's very funny, but it's wrong.

568.88.text: .."an informal coterie of"... You lose five points.

573.36.text: and "a style of post-war drama that emphasised drab, domestic settings"?

581.64.text: Come on, one of you buzz from St Hilda's.

586.12.text: No, it's just kitchen, so I can't accept that, I'm afraid.

589.24.text: I must accept what you say.

591.84.text: Who is the only fictional character to have been given

594.28.text: a full page obituary in the...?

603.40.text: Your bonuses are on words, St Hilda's.

606.44.text: The Washington Post runs an annual competition

609.44.text: to find new meanings for existing words.

612.52.text: Thus, flabbergasted has been defined as being

615.68.text: "appalled at the amount of weight or flab one has gained".

620.00.text: Get it? So identify the word in each case.

622.48.text: Firstly, usually denoting a familiar beverage,

625.72.text: what six-letter word has been defined as

636.24.text: Secondly, what eight-letter verb has been defined as

639.60.text: "to give up or relinquish any hope of having a flat stomach"?

660.00.text: usually denotes an embarrassing bodily function,

662.68.text: but in this context means "the emergency vehicle

665.60.text: "that picks one up after being run over by a steam roller"?

677.92.text: Aesop's fable of The Fox And The Grapes

680.68.text: is a classic but anachronistic illustration

685.76.text: It was first identified in the 1950s by Leon Festinger,

689.44.text: and is defined as "a feeling of discomfort that occurs

692.64.text: "when one holds two conflicting ideas at the same time".

703.68.text: These bonuses are on Greece, St Hilda's.

706.04.text: In each case, I want the name of an island group.

708.64.text: Firstly, the name of which island group resembles that of

711.92.text: the Platonic solid whose faces are regular pentagons?

723.60.text: Which island group has a name relating to an English word

729.32.text: "such as those in internal combustion engines"?

736.56.text: Which island group has a name that is etymologically related

739.28.text: to an English word meaning scattered or dispersed?

752.92.text: Sorry, we're not on that one.

755.96.text: Right, we're going to take another starter question now.

760.64.text: "that stupid, yellow, circular face now known simply as the smiley."

768.68.text: by Mike Garry and Joe Duddle.

771.52.text: To which cultural figure are they referring, a part owner of

774.84.text: Factory Records and the founder of Manchester's Hacienda nightclub?

788.56.text: Lady Jane Grey was born in 1537.

807.56.text: No, she was his younger sister.

808.96.text: As part of an attempt to divert the royal succession,

815.32.text: to Guildford Dudley, the son of which duke?

- Edward VII? No. 
- No.

895.12.text: and the single-word subtitle by which it's usually known.

979.52.text:

983.60.text: It's his second symphony, usually known as the Resurrection.

986.16.text: And finally, name this work and this composer.

1034.96.text: of Right Wing Women - The Politics Of Domesticated Females?

1062.64.text: and greed of the stock market?

1070.48.text: It is Serious Money, yes. APPLAUSE

1075.04.text: Right these bonuses are on the rhetorical device known as anaphora,

1078.36.text: that is, the repetition of a word or phrase in close occurrence.

1082.60.text: Firstly, anaphora is the dominant figure of speech

1674.32.text: in the final of this Christmas series to St Hilda's College Oxford.
